sen.j: ヒトツモノは社寺の祭・法会などで行われる神事・行事の一つ。
sen.e: Hitotsu mono is a Buddhism or Shinto ritual/event held in festivals or gatherings in the shrine and the temple.
Hitotsumono is a Buddhism or Shinto ritual/event held in festivals or gatherings in shrines and temples.

sen.j: 稚児などの扮装した人あるいは人形がヒトツモノと呼ばれ、神幸祭などに加わるものと、何らかの儀式を行うものがある。
sen.e: A person or a doll dressed in a chigo (a boy acolyte) costume called Hitotsu mono participates a devine procession or performs a rite.

sen.j: 一般的には一つ物、一ツ物などと表記されており、文献史料では一物、一者とも表記されていた。
sen.e: Hitotsu mono is written as "一つ物" or "一ツ物" in common, and also as "一物"or "一者" in the historical materials.

sen.e: In theJapanese folklore, there is an established theory that Hitotsu mono is a yorishiro(a spiritualistic medium), or a relic of yorishiro while there is a different theory that Hitotsu mono originates in furyu(divine dance).

sen.e: Uma osa was furyu, a divine dance performed by a child who rode on a horse dedicated by the Imperial Court that was held in goryoe(a sprit-pacifying ceremony)of Yasaka-jinja Shrine.

sen.e: In the later Heian period, Hitotsu mono first appeared in the historical documents, for example, in the description of the local Shinto deity in the "Cyuyuki"(a diary of a court official).

sen.j: 田楽・流鏑馬・競馬・相撲・王の舞・獅子舞などとともに行われていた事例が多い。
sen.e: Hitotsu mono has been frequently held along with other performances such as denraku(ritual dance and music), yabusame(horseback archery), horse racing, sumo, the king dance and shishimai(lion dance).

sen.j: 王の舞と同じように、これら一連の芸能を構成する一つの芸能として平安後期の畿内の祭礼・法会でヒトツモノは成立し、中世に各地に伝播していったと考えられている。
sen.e: In the later Heian period, like the king dance, as one of such a series of performance arts, Hitotsu mono was established in the festivals or Buddhism gatherings in the countries near Kyoto prefecture, and in Medieval period, it spread to various regions.

sen.j: 一般的に童児が勤めること、ウマなどで移動することが多く、中には地面に足をつけることを禁忌としている事例があること、ヤマドリの尾羽や紙垂をつけた笠を被り、化粧をしていることなどがヒトツモノの特徴として挙げられている。
sen.e: Hitotsu mono is generally characterized by a child performing the role, riding a horse(in some rituals, setting his foot on the ground was tabooed), wearing a hat decorated with tail feathers of a mountain bird or paper strips, and being made up.

Hitotsumono is generally characterized by a child performing a role, riding a horse (in some rituals, setting his foot on the ground was taboo), wearing a hat decorated with tail feathers of a mountain bird or paper strips, and being made up.

sen.e: Hitotsumono is generally characterized by a child performing a role, riding a horse (in some rituals, setting his foot on the ground was taboo), wearing a hat decorated with tail feathers of a mountain bird or paper strips, and being made up.

sen.j: これらの特徴を幼童信仰の影響、地面に足をつけないのは神聖視されているため、装飾と化粧は依坐になるための道具と考察した。
sen.e: The above characteristics were considered as the influence of yodo shinko(a belief that worships young children), for example, without setting his foot on the ground signified his divinity, and the decoration and make-up were the implements for a yorishiro.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: また神幸行列において重要な位置を占めていると考えられたことや芸を伴わないことなどから、依坐であるという解釈がなされた。
sen.e: Also, occupying a significant position in the divine procession, and without performing arts, Hitotsuno mono was interpreted as a yorishiro.

sen.j: この解釈のもとではヒトツモノという名称は一つ・少数を意味すると考えられている。
sen.e: Hitotsu mono is considered to mean "one thing" or "fewness" from the above interpretation.
Hitotsumono is considered to mean "one thing" or "fewness" from the above interpretation.

sen.j: 一方で、神幸行列などにおいて馬上であることは特別なことではなく、また装飾と化粧は風流でも見られるものであり、前述の特徴は宗教的な意味が特に強いものではなく、ヒトツモノは依坐ではなかったとの解釈もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, there is a different interpretation that Hitotsu mono was not a yorishiro because the characteristics described previously didn't have special religious meanings when a horseback riding in a divine procession was not unique, and furyu also had decoration and make-up.

sen.j: この解釈のもとでは、ヒトツモノという語は一番目立つという意味で、かつては流行した風流のことをヒトツモノと呼んでいたと考えている。
sen.e: According to the different interpretation, it is thought Hitotsu mono meant "the most prominent thing" and furyu, once in fashion, was called Hitotsu mono.

sen.j: 流行の風流であった馬長をヒトツモノと呼んだが、それそのものがヒトツモノと呼ばれるようになり、後に各地で民俗変容が起き、依坐であると認識されるようになったと説明している。
sen.e: In the explanation, Uma osa, which was a popular furyu, was initially called Hitostu mono and furyu itself came to be called Hitotsu mono, which was latterly recognized as yorishiro due to transformation of folklore in various regions.
